author: .vbuterin
content: What would state being partially active mean in such a system?

author: ladidan
content:
Basically what you try to avoid in a system like that is an immediate *complete* devaluation of all of the 'state' (i.e. book value of a given article), because it leads to an immediate equivalent decrease in your P/L (which from a steering perspective is usually undesireable). so by applying a gradual/smooth transition dependent on the movement frequency, the immediate impact on your P/L is less severe. partially active in this case therefor means a reduction in value of state over a given time period (e.g. every 12m from 1$->0,5$->0,25$->0,1%->0$). physically though, the stock is always on stock until it's worth zero.
it's a bit over the top over my head whether in our context here a state between 1=active and 0=inactive serves any additional value for the given purpose of reducing state bloat

author: chat-bridge
content: <vbuterin> hmm, I think you might be misunderstanding

author: chat-bridge
content: <vbuterin> State expiring doesn't mean its value drops to zero

author: chat-bridge
content: <vbuterin> If your state expires, you can easily recover it by just providing a witness

author: chat-bridge
content: <dankrad> the value changes from "value of state" to "value of state - cost of providing witness"

author: ladidan
content:
yes, you're right. and "value of state - cost of providing witness" reduces overall state size as opposed to "value of state", correct?
in my conception the above described method was only meant to be sort of a scoring system

author: chat-bridge
content: <vbuterin> But how would you make it a sliding scale? Add the requirement to provide part of a witness? How would that even work?

author: chat-bridge
content: <vbuterin> Arguably providing a witness already gets harder over time the more expired some object is

author: chat-bridge
content: <dankrad> technically you always have a transaction cost when selling value

author: chat-bridge
content: <dankrad> so the question is, how often would the reactivation witness even exceed transaction cost

author: ladidan
content:
i apologize for being unable to argue in more technical terms, but keeping it childlike simplistic: if i think of eth state as my packed warehouse and my intention is to keep its size as small as possible and not necessarily want to nuke all of it every 6m (ReGenesis?), I would extract a list of e.g. my top10 non-movers by value (=state size in bits/bytes), gradually mark them as less valuable if moved infrequently and not touched in the meantime, until i can remove them of my warehouse (=zero state size). a key question i guess in eth state terms is: if i wanted that, does a non-mover marked as less valuable save state size anyways?
i assume the marginal input of the idea is very much just the differentiation between "value of state size" and "state size in terms of bits/bytes"

author: stri8ted
content: A contract/state that is accessed infrequently, can still be accessed at any given block, so "removing" them, means you would not be able to process blocks that accessed this state, and thus any blocks that followed. State either exists or does not. There is no in between.

author: stri8ted
content: You could attempt to optimize on the client side, by storing less accessed state on disk vs ram, but the fundamental storage requirements are not reduced.
